title: A Comprehensive Review of Fuzzy Expert Systems for Region Specific Crop Recommendation
authors: Arpit Subhash, Gaurav Kumar Patel, Nikita
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Agriculture remains the fortitude of food security, yet determining in crop selection is challenged by various uncertainties in soil availability, climatic availability and resource availability. This review evaluates application of FES for region-specific crop recommendation. Total 20 peer-research papers published between 2019-2025 have been analyzed using the PREFERRED REPORTING ITEMS FOR SYSTEMATIC REVIEWS AND META ANALYSIS (PRISMA) framework. The analysis highlights key research questions addressed, crop types and regions studied, input parameters utilized, fuzzy variables, membership functions, inference mechanisms, and decision rules applied. Integrations with techniques such as GIS, AHP, rough set theory, and spectral sensing are also synthesized. Inference mechanisms like Mamdani FIS, Rough-Fuzzy Hybrids integrating with other techniques like GIS, AHP, Rough Sets have demonstrated higher accuracy rates, interpretability and adaptability. However, most approaches remain case-specific, computationally intensive, and weakly validated against real-world farming outcomes. Challenges like limited scalability, insufficient integration with real time IOT and lack of hybridization with AI/ML techniques are the major gaps identified in this review. There is a need of comprehensive hybrid FES for mapping progress, limitations and future opportunities of Fuzzy Expert Systems in agriculture decision-making, with emphasis on building scalable, farmer-centric and intelligent crop recommendation models.

title: Digital Twin–Enabled Personalized Clinical Trials with Reliable and Explainable Data Pipelines using Organic Synthesis Model
authors: David Raju Kuppala, R.Hariharan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The conventional clinical trials are frequently characterized by a lack of personalization, low levels of data reliability and low levels of interpretation, which restrict their use in real-life. The present paper suggests a personalized clinical trial model (DTOC) that incorporates organic synthesis-based drug modeling, multi-omics data fusion, and interpretable artificial intelligence (XAI)-based reliability pipelines with the help of digital twins. Physiology of every patient is simulated as a digital twin and provides an opportunity to simulate genomic, clinical, and quality-of-life signs in real-time. The organic synthesis module is the approximation of the drug-patient interaction on the molecular level, and the XAI layer increases the transparency and compliance with the requirements of GDPR and IEEE principles on AI ethics. Experimental validation with 500 patient datasets showed that it gained significant performance improvement, obtaining 92.3% and XAI reliability of 0.89 and improved in the reliability index by 16% over the baseline deep-learning-based methods. The suggested DTOC framework would guarantee reproducible, interpretable, and ethically consistent trial outcomes. Through the combination of customized drug production and explainable digital health simulation, this study enhances the future of customized clinical trials that can hasten the process of drug discovery, enhance health outcomes, and increase confidence in the AI-driven healthcare systems.

title: Masked Contrastive Pre-Training for Few-Shot Medical Image Classification
authors: SRK.Juhi Reashma, M. Sakthivanitha, Kavitha G, Vishwa Priya V, Gayathri B, D. Ranjith
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The challenge of few-shot medical image classification is partially due to a scarcity of annotated data, and the additional challenge of fine-grained feature discrimination. To this end, we have proposed a novel framework called Masked Region-Guided Contrastive Pretraining (MRGCP) that leverages masked region modeling within contrastive learning to improve representation learning in low-data scenarios. MRGCP uses unsupervised saliency detection to identify discriminative regions, randomly masks salient and non-salient patches, and jointly optimizes a global contrastive loss, a region-aware contrastive loss, and a masked reconstruction loss. MRGCP showed a significant improvement over well known self-supervised approaches including SimCLR, MoCo v2, and Masked Autoencoders on established few-shot medical image classification benchmark tasks. For example, MRGCP achieved an accuracy ranking of 70.8% and surpassed the next best approach by more than 4% on a 5-way 1-shot experiments, with consistent improvements found in AUC and macro F1-Score metrics. These results indicate that jointly aligning global and region-level embeddings while reconstructing masked regions produced features that were more robust and transferable. Overall, we believe MRGCP provides a useful approach to improve few-shot learning performance in medical imaging domains.

title: Classification and Prediction of Property Taxes using Various Machine Learning Models
authors: Neha Tripathi, Sadirdin Khudoykulov, Kishibay Kudiyarov, Muzaffar Shojonov, Pankaj Kumar, Bekzod Madaminov
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Accurate assessments of property taxes are important to inject more equity, transparency, and efficiency in local government revenue generation. Traditional statistical and rule-based approaches have often failed to consider the complexity of, and nonlinear relationships inherent with property features like location, area and market value which contributes to unreliability of tax assessment predictions. We leverage several machine learning (ML) models including Linear Regression, Decision Tree, Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, and Neural Networks to classify and predict property taxes using an extensive dataset of property features and historical tax assessments. We evaluate model performance using Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score. Experimental results show that ensemble learning methods including Gradient Boosting and Random Forest demonstrated improved accuracy and generalizability over classical statistical and deep learning modelling approaches. Our main conclusion is that machine learning shows the potential for a scalable alternative to property tax assessment automation. The implications of our study demonstrate a shift toward the modernized development of tax systems, adopting data-driven approaches for political formulation, fairness, and generating forecasting municipal revenue.

title: Empowering Agriculture Products with QR Code Verification and Sentiment Analysis
authors: Ramadevi K, Shalini R, Radhika A, Poojasri M
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The proliferation of fake agricultural products jeopardises consumer safety and threatens the livelihoods of legitimate producers. This paper introduces a comprehensive framework that leverages QR code verification and sentiment analysis to address these challenges within the agricultural supply chain. Every product is given a unique QR code, which allows customers to verify the legality of the product and obtain comprehensive details about its distribution and place of origin. Concurrently, the incorporation of sentiment analysis provides insightful information about customer comments, helping consumers make well-informed decisions while reducing the impact of false reviews. The approach not only empowers customers by increasing openness and trust, but it also provides farmers with actionable data to better understand market patterns, negotiate fair prices, and lessen their reliance on intermediaries. The success of the suggested framework in enhancing product traceability, building consumer trust, and advancing a more robust and reliable agricultural marketplace is demonstrated by a thorough evaluation.

title: Real-Time Decision Optimization in Satellite-Ground Links using Edge Computing and Artificial Intelligence
authors: Vijayanand Selvaraj
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Satellite-ground communication systems demand real-time optimization to maintain reliability, low latency, and high throughput under dynamic conditions. Conventional cloud-based decision systems often suffer from delay and limited adaptability due to centralized processing. This paper proposes an edge-computing framework enhanced with artificial intelligence for real-time decision optimization in satellite communication. The system integrates long short-term memory (LSTM) networks for predictive link forecasting and a deep Q-network (DQN) reinforcement learning model for adaptive link control. Simulation results in NS-3 show that the proposed framework reduces decision latency by 37.5%, increases throughput by up to 17%, and improves packet delivery ratio under interference and congestion scenarios compared to cloud-based baselines. The design achieves low inference times and operates effectively on compact edge devices, demonstrating its potential for resilient and autonomous satellite-ground communication.

title: Reactive Power Capability of Grid-Connected High-Power Hydrogen Electrolyzers Fed by Current Source Rectifiers
authors: Javier I. Beaumont, Álvaro Iribarren, Ernesto L. Barrios, Ianko Valero, Alfredo Ursúa, Pablo Sanchis
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: Grid-connected high-power electrolyzers must comply with increasingly demanding regulations regarding their connection to the grid and particularly their reactive power exchange. Current source rectifier (CSR) is a promising topology as it offers single-stage, step-down conversion and adjustable power factor. However, its reactive power capability depends on the input capacitance, the grid voltage and the electrolyzer polarization characteristics, which changes with technology and ageing. This paper presents an analytical framework and develops reactive power expressions that link those parameters to the maximum reactive power absorption and supply capability. The analysis is applied to two electrolyzer technologies: a 5.8 MW alkaline (AEL) and a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6. 1 6 ~ M W}$</tex> proton exchange membrane (PEM). Results show how the analysis can provide practical sizing guidelines for designing and optimizing CSR-fed electrolysis plants to ensure grid code conformity.

title: Intelligent Federated Cloud Scheduling with Transfer Learning and Hybrid Reinforcement-Meta-Heuristic Optimization
authors: Balaji K, S. Silvia Priscila, Praveen B M
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Cloud computing has transformed the sharing of the resources and service delivery but effective scheduling of tasks across federated multi-clouds environment is a difficult task because of the heterogeneous nature of resources, dynamic nature of workloads, and SLA constraints. Current solutions tend to be either local or global at the cost of other. This paper presents a proposal of an Intelligent Federated Cloud Scheduling model that combines transfer learning based on predictive workload modeling and a hybrid reinforcement-meta-heuristic optimization of dynamic task allocation. The framework was tested on the Google Cluster Trace dataset, where it was compared to five state-of-the-art algorithms, with a decrease in makespan of 15 percent, energy usage reduced by 12 percent, SLA violation rate of 2.5 percent and resource utilization efficiency of 92 percent. The findings indicate the scalability, strength and viability of the framework to process dynamic and heterogeneous workloads. This paper presents the promise of predictive AI with hybrid optimization on intelligent cloud management, which provides a general understanding of practical research on automated, energy-efficient, and SLA-compliant federated cloud scheduling.

title: Single-Stage AC/AC Converter for Solid-State Transformer (SST) Based on Modified DAB Topology
authors: Wajahat Khan, Roberto Petrella, Mukesh Kumar Pathak
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: This paper presents a single-stage AC/AC converter for solid-state transformer (SST) application. The proposed solution exhibits a non-resonant topology based on a modified version of the Dual Active Bridge (DAB) and does not require four quadrant AC switches for direct AC/AC conversion, thus eliminating the associated commutation management and related issues. Also, the topology does not need Line-Frequency (LF) operated unfolding bridges, resulting in a reduced device count. Extended Phase-Shift (EPS) modulation is considered and full analytical calculations of the zero-voltage Switching (ZVS) regions are provided, demonstrating the capability to operate the converter over a wide range with complete ZVS. Experimental results are presented to validate the proposal and the associated analysis. Both rated and low power operation over a large part of the input AC cycle ranging from the peak value to near the zerocrossing point are shown and discussed.

title: Security and Protection in Modern Operating Systems: A Comprehensive Review
authors: Shagun Mantri, Taniya Shah, Durgesh M. Sharma, Nisha Bhushan Gongal
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The contemporary operating system is undergoing previously unseen security pressures as they are placed under pressure in a more interconnected digital environment. This general survey explores the present condition of security and safeguard measures in the modern operating systems and highlights the four vital facets in this regard: access control and user authentication, malware and OS-level threats, sandboxing and isolation techniques, and secure operating system design. We review how Discretionary Access Control (DAC) has evolved into Mandatory Access Control (MAC) systems, the increasingly advanced kinds of malware exploiting vulnerabilities in operating systems, and the degree to which possible isolation and sandboxing strategies work, as well as secure operating systems like SELinux. The analysis carried out shows that despite the drastic improvements in OS security procedures, the highly dynamic threat environment requires additional ingenuity in security measures. The recommendations for future research directions on operating system security have been outlined at the end of the paper.

title: A Comprehensive Study on Olympic Data Analysis for Predicting Performance Trends using Machine Learning Algorithm
authors: Satyam Raval, Aaryan Mavani, Sakshi Munde, Riddhi Panchal, Snehlata Wankhade, Gopal Sakarkar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The Olympic Games during their 120 years history furnishes a large mass of facts which recording the athletic victories as the sports development follows countries participation statistics. The study takes advantage of machine training to analyze previous Olympics performances that assist in creating medallion winning prediction. A dataset composed of 271,000 records containing 53 sports events and 306 attended by 207 countries and 7 significant statistical characteristics supports this study. Random Forest and are applied in the analysis XGBoost classifiers in order to create a predictive model. The Random Forest model provided accuracy of 86.9% at its first stage but its class imbalance minimized the prediction of the winner’s issue. XGBoost classifier was shown to be better generalization performance although it decreased in level of accuracy 86.4%. Applying Synthetic Minority Over-Sampling Technique the prediction was enhanced by (SMOTE) on the software system accuracy of medal winners. XGBoost model that was constructed with numerical scaling and categorical encoding and feature scaling and temporal feature extraction achieved a rate of accuracy of 87% and accuracy scores of 0.91 and 0.49 of non-medalists and medalists respectively that defined a best precision recall balance. The trend analysis analysis with the historical trend and competition changes results in improved strategic sport analytics in coming up with better strategic decisions. Research results show machine learning is also a potent solution to sports analytics because it creates data-driven ways of athlete performance assessment and enhances future prediction of the Olympic events accuracy.

title: Electrical and Thermal Characterization of PCB-Embedded 650 V GaN Half-Bridges on AlN Substrates
authors: Dominik Koch, Vladimir Polezhaev, Aline Reck, Michael Bosch, Jeremy Nuzzo, Mathias C.J. Weiser, Till Huesgen, Ingmar Kallfass
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: GaN power transistors require packaging concepts that combine low parasitic inductance with excellent thermal management for demanding converter applications. Therefore in this work, a hybrid half-bridge package embedding two discrete 650 V GaN transistors on AIN DBC is proposed, combining module-level thermal performance with the electrical advantages and flexibility of discrete SMD packages and embedding technologies. Static measurements show no significant differences in transfer characteristics, leakage currents (all <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$I_{\text {DS, leak }}<1 \mu \mathrm{A}$</tex> at 600 V), or capacitances compared to reference samples. The package achieves a thermal resistance <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{R}_{\mathbf{t h, j - c}}$</tex> below <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.2 \mathrm{K} / \mathrm{W}$</tex> and a parasitic power loop inductance below <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6 0 0} \mathbf{~ p H}$</tex>, with power loop resistance close to twice the nominal <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R_{\text{DS}, \text { on }}$</tex>. This approach enables compact, lowinductive, and thermally efficient half-bridge integration for high-performance power converter applications.

title: A Review on Load Balancing Framework for Efficient Resource Scheduling in Cloud-based Healthcare Systems
authors: Kalai Selvi T, Dr.S.Sasirekha, Mirudula K
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Cloud computing plays a transformative role in modern healthcare by enabling scalable, flexible, and cost-efficient data processing across distributed environments. However, achieving effective workload balancing in the Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) model remains a major challenge due to dynamic workloads, heterogeneous resources, and energy efficiency constraints. Existing frameworks often experience increased latency, high computational overhead, and limited adaptability under fluctuating loads. To address these challenges, this study introduces an enhanced load balancing framework based on hybrid metaheuristic optimization techniques—Ant Lion Optimization (ALO) and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO). The proposed system initializes and configures virtual machines and hosts, performs iterative VM-to-host mapping, and optimizes power consumption while maintaining high performance. Through intelligent task scheduling and adaptive optimization, the hybrid ALO–PSO model achieves improved load distribution, scalability, and sustainability compared to existing methods. The results demonstrate that the proposed framework enhances energy efficiency, reduces execution time, and ensures reliable service delivery for cloud-based healthcare applications, contributing to the advancement of intelligent and sustainable cloud computing infrastructure.

title: Enhanced Current Balancing Between Parallel Si IGBTs and SiC MOSFET by Co-Switching in High-Power Inverters
authors: Danielle Jaye S. Agron, Patrick R. Palmer, Stephen Makonin
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: This study investigates current balancing among parallel IGBTs through a coordinated switching (co-switching) strategy implemented using heterogeneous devices, specifically SiC MOSFET and Si IGBTs. The approach employs asynchronous gate-drive timing at turn-on and turn-off between the SiC MOSFET and the IGBTs within an asymmetric topology. Experimental validation is performed on a hardware test rig that features two IGBTs parallel to a SiC MOSFET. The results show that the proposed co-switching method significantly improves current sharing between the IGBTs, particularly under high module current at 300 A. The experiment reveals that the use of asynchronous timing further enhances the current distribution across the parallel devices.

title: Smart Waste Segregation Bin
authors: Nikila C, Ms. Nirmala C, Kavinkumar V, Kavibharathi P, Sathishkumar K, Akash S
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Smart Waste Segregation Bin is a mechanism that uses an Arduino UNO microcontroller board to control sensors and actuators for automatic garbage collection and segregation. The mechanism involves the usage of ultrasonic sensor, Infrared (IR) sensor, soil moisture sensor, and DC motor with L298N motor driver to perform different activities. The primary objective is to recognize the waste and move the system towards the waste, preventing obstacles with the help of ultrasonic and proximity sensing. The soil moisture sensor is also incorporated to sense the wet waste and sort them into their respective part of the bin.The primary operation of the system relies on the IR sensor, which detects the waste, and the robotic system moves towards the waste location. Ultrasonic sensors recognize the distance of the obstacles around, guiding the movement of the system, and ensuring efficient collection of waste with no collision. Proximity sensor also allows the system's obstacle-avoiding feature in real time. The use of the L298N motor driver IC allows for controlling the DC motor with precision, enabling the robotic system to move closer or further from the detected waste or obstacles. This project demonstrates the functional prototype of a waste management solution, taking a role in automation of garbage collection, environmental monitoring, and real-time obstacle avoidance, hence making waste management more efficient and sustainable.

title: Multi-Model Framework for Assessing Depression, Anxiety and Sleep Disorders
authors: A. Divya, D. Sree Lakshmi, P. Nikitha, R. Sai Roshini, V. Keerthi Reddy, Sk. Sahira
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Psychological health disorders like depression, anxiety and sleep disorders are the growing problems around the world. To overcome these issues, diagnosis methods are needed. Existing research relied mostly on self-reported questionnaires like SCL-90, but these assessments are relatively subjective and often are limited to single disorders which lead to lesser accuracies. This study proposes a machine learning approach that helps in the detection of depression, anxiety and sleep disorders and also helps in classifying them individually. The dataset contains 783 subjects with PHQ score, GAD score, BMI, age, gender and Epworth scale score as the attributes. Preprocessing include imputation, categorical encoding and normalization before classifying. Several Machine Learning methods show their usefulness in the healthcare field. The study examines how classification algorithms like Logistic Regression, Support Vector Machine and Random Forest perform to detect multiple psychological health disorders with respect to performance and accuracy. The results show that SVM achieved the highest accuracy of 97.45% for sleep disorder detection, while Logistic Regression and Random Forest achieved 96.82% and 96.80% respectively. The proposed methods are reliable to support the psychological health screening.

title: AI and IoT Powered Smart Pillow for Early Detection and Management of Sleep Apnea
authors: S. Saju, V. Madhanraj, N. Saravanan, S. Sivapriya
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA) is a common, but largely undiagnosed sleep disorder often associated with both cardiovascular and cognitive consequences. Traditional ways to diagnose OSA like polysomnography (PSG) do provide accurate data but are costly, complicated, and generally not conducive to long term monitoring in the home. This work proposes an AI-enabled smart pillow incorporating pressure, acoustic, and photoplethysmography (PPG) sensors for non-invasive monitoring of breathing patterns, snoring, and apnea events. Embedded physiologically based signal-processing algorithms and machine-learning classifiers (Support Vector Machine and Random Forest) achieved greater than 90% accuracy with reference to the PSG data. In addition, the smart pillow includes an IoT-enabled mobile interface for real time monitoring, feedback, and personalized vibration-based intervention during apnea events. Experimental validation of the device using ten participants demonstrated a strong correlation with PSG (r = 0.94) and a user comfort rating of 4.6/5. The smart pillow can provide sleep health professionals a streamlined, comfortable, and cost-effective option for assessment using home-based practices. Future applications will include large-scale model validation, adaptive AI driven optimization, as well as telemedicine incorporation for ongoing sleep health screenings and monitoring.

title: Prediction of Mammogram Image Performance using ResNet and Random Forest-based Model
authors: Nazma Sultana Shaik, Hemanta Kumar Bhuyan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: This paper has emphasized breast cancer detection analysis using a deep learning model. Although breast cancer detection has been developed using different methods, it is still necessary to test the breast cancer image dataset to improve performance. Thus, we have considered the ResNet model with the Random Forest method to evaluate the Mammogram dataset. We have modified the existing ResNet model using the Random Forest method to improve performance. Different technical approaches are used to enhance the ResNet model such as input shape, optimizer, pretrained model and dense layers. The combination of ResNet and Random Forest model improve each performance of experiments. The proposed model is demonstrated over several epochs and with several evaluation metrics using the MIAS dataset. The model achieved 98% accuracy at the highest epoch, and the Random Forest method achieved 98.42% accuracy.

title: NLP based Gesture Translation Recognition for Inclusive Communication
authors: Ramya Cauvery D, L.JosephineUsha
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Sign language is an important means of communication for people that are deaf, hard of hearing, or speech impaired. However, there are still barriers to communication between signers and non-signers, which limits productive communication. There are several types of sign language systems, but there are limitations to most sign language systems based on cost, language specificity, or lack of cross-system interoperability. In this article we present an intelligent and low-cost system to bridge this divide. In the system proposed in this paper, we undertake two processes: (1) we first convert audio input to text output through the Google Speech API, and (2) next we take that text output and generate images and videos of sign gestures based on natural language processing (NLP) techniques and convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture. The training data includes static and dynamic recognitions of English and Indian Sign Language (ISL) gestures of random combinations. In conclusion, users' transition quality with our HySign-Transformer system translates reasonably well into human understanding and overcomes many limitations of existing sign to speech solutions. The proposed HySign Transformer system we have opened a new method of immediate inclusive communication between speech and sign language.
